user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_unmount:
```c
int lfs_unmount(lfs_t *lfs) {
    int err = LFS_LOCK(lfs->cfg);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }
    LFS_TRACE("lfs_unmount(%p)", (void*)lfs);

    err = lfs_unmount_(lfs);

    LFS_TRACE("lfs_unmount -> %d", err);
    LFS_UNLOCK(lfs->cfg);
    return err;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function lfs_unmount:
static int lfs_unmount_(lfs_t *lfs) {
    return lfs_deinit(lfs);
}
...
static int lfs_deinit(lfs_t *lfs) {
    // free allocated memory
    if (!lfs->cfg->read_buffer) {
        lfs_free(lfs->rcache.buffer);
    }

    if (!lfs->cfg->prog_buffer) {
        lfs_free(lfs->pcache.buffer);
    }

    if (!lfs->cfg->lookahead_buffer) {
        lfs_free(lfs->lookahead.buffer);
    }

    return 0;
}
...
#define LFS_LOCK(cfg) ((void)cfg,0)
...
#define LFS_UNLOCK(cfg) ((void)cfg)
...
#define LFS_TRACE(__VA_ARGS__) 
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I found no uses of any of the <string.h> functions named by MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 (memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn) in the provided code fragments. lfs_unmount calls lfs_unmount_ which calls lfs_deinit; lfs_deinit performs pointer checks and calls lfs_free but does not use any string.h functions. The macros LFS_LOCK, LFS_UNLOCK, and LFS_TRACE are defined as no-ops in the provided code, so they do not introduce string function calls. Therefore there are no code fragments in the supplied code that require investigation for Rule 21.17. (If implementations not shown here — for example lfs_free or other omitted functions/macros — call any string.h functions, those implementations should be inspected.)
